1. Ventilation (VE) - This refers to the process of moving air in and out of the lungs, which is an essential function of the respiratory system. While ventilation itself is not a disease, it can be affected by various respiratory diseases or disorders, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pneumonia, or asthma.
2. Tidal volume (VT) - Tidal volume refers to the amount of air inspired or expelled during a single breath. Abnormal tidal volume can be a sign of various respiratory diseases, such as COPD, pneumonia, or pulmonary fibrosis.
3. Inspiratory time (TI) - Inspiratory time refers to the duration of the inspiratory phase of breathing, which is the time it takes to inhale air into the lungs. Abnormal inspiratory time can be a sign of respiratory muscle weakness or fatigue, which can be caused by various neuromuscular diseases, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) or muscular dystrophy.
4. Expiratory time (TE) - Expiratory time refers to the duration of the expiratory phase of breathing, which is the time it takes to exhale air from the lungs. Abnormal expiratory time can be a sign of respiratory muscle weakness or fatigue, similar to inspiratory time.
5. Breathing frequency (f) - Breathing frequency refers to the number of breaths per minute. Abnormal breathing frequency can be a sign of various respiratory diseases, such as COPD, pneumonia, or asthma, as well as other conditions such as anxiety or panic attacks.
6. Mean inspiratory flow (VT/TI) - Mean inspiratory flow refers to the average rate at which air flows into the lungs during the inspiratory phase of breathing. Abnormal mean inspiratory flow can be a sign of respiratory diseases or disorders that affect lung compliance, such as COPD or pulmonary fibrosis.

* Mean inspiratory flow (VT/TI)
